ENGL 110.title: ENGL 110
ENGL 110.name: First-Year Writing
ENGL 110.description: Introduction to the process of academic writing that centers on the composition of analytical, research-based essays.

ENGL 312.title: ENGL 312
ENGL 312.name: Written Communications in Business
ENGL 312.description: Examines the role of written communication in corporate decision making. Students write memos, letters, proposals and reports that simulate on-the-job communication tasks, and are encouraged to use materials from their fields of specialization.

ENGL 410.title: ENGL 410
ENGL 410.name: Technical Writing
ENGL 410.description: Selected problems in technical communications, the preparation of reports and technical editing.

CISC 108.title: CISC 108
CISC 108.name: Introduction to Computer Science I
CISC 108.description: Computing and principles of programming with an emphasis on systematic program design. Topics include functional programming, data abstraction, procedural abstraction, use of control and state, recursion, testing, and object-oriented programming concepts. Requires no prior programming experience, open to any major, but intended primarily for majors and minors in computer science or mathematics.

CISC 181.title: CISC 181
CISC 181.name: Introduction to Computer Science II
CISC 181.description: Principles of computer science illustrated and applied through programming in an object oriented language. Programming projects illustrate computational problems, styles and issues that arise in computer systems development and in all application areas of computation.

CISC 210.title: CISC 210
CISC 210.name: Introduction to Systems Programming
CISC 210.description: Principles of computer systems programming for software and hardware platforms to achieve efficient resource usage. Topics include the C programming language, memory management, and awareness of system constraints and interfacing. Projects include programming embedded systems and interactive objects.

CISC 220.title: CISC 220
CISC 220.name: Data Structures
CISC 220.description: Review of data type abstraction, recursion, arrays, stacks, queues, multiple stacks and linked lists. Emphasis on dynamic storage management, garbage collection, trees, graphs, tables, sorting and searching.

CISC 260.title: CISC 260
CISC 260.name: Machine Organization and Assembly Language
CISC 260.description: Introduction to the basics of machine organization. Programming tools and techniques at the machine and assembly levels. Assembly language programming and computer arithmetic techniques.

CISC 275.title: CISC 275
CISC 275.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
CISC 275.description: Object oriented software design and development through use of an object oriented programming language. Topics include team programming, design patterns, graphical user interfaces, software engineering tools (e.g., integrated development environments, version control, build management, bug tracking, automated testing).

CISC 303.title: CISC 303
CISC 303.name: Automata Theory
CISC 303.description: Automata and formal language theory. Background for advanced applications in compilers, computer networks, operating systems, and natural language processing. Finite automata and regular languages. Push down automata and context free grammars. Turing machines.

CISC 320.title: CISC 320
CISC 320.name: Introduction to Algorithms
CISC 320.description: Design and analysis of algorithms: worst/average case analysis, proofs for correctness and performance of algorithms. Algorithmic strategies (divtitlee and conquer, greedy methods, dynamic programming, etc.). Algorithms for searching, forming and traversal of strings, trees and graphs. Categorization of computational problems: classes P and NP. NP completeness.

CISC 361.title: CISC 361
CISC 361.name: Operating Systems
CISC 361.description: Principles and techniques employed in the development of operating systems and their control programs. Includes management of memory, processors, I/O devices.

CISC 372.title: CISC 372
CISC 372.name: Parallel Computing
CISC 372.description: Introduction to parallel computing concepts, methodologies, and tools. Programming and algorithmic techniques for code that will run simultaneously on parallel computing architectures. Topics include: single and multi-core parallelism, shared and distributed memory architectures, concurrency, program decomposition, data distribution, communication, load balancing, scalability, locality, granularity, debugging, performance evaluation.

CISC 498.title: CISC 498
CISC 498.name: Computer Science Senior Design Project I
CISC 498.description: First semester of two-semester senior software design course.  Students work in teams to develop solutions to real-world problems for a client.  Application of a modern software engineering process; requirement solicitation, analysis, and specification; prototyping; design; incremental development; testing and verification; client interaction; and presentation. Offered in Fall only.

CISC 499.title: CISC 499
CISC 499.name: Computer Science Senior Design Project II

CISC 355.title: CISC 355
CISC 355.name: Computers, Ethics, and Society
CISC 355.description: Explains relationships among information technology, society and ethics by examining issues raised by increasingly wtitleespread use of computers. Topics include ethics for computer professionals, computer impact on factory work, office work, personal privacy and social power distribution.
requirements: Additional Reqs, University Breadth, CAS Breadth A

CISC 304.title: CISC 304
CISC 304.name: Logic for Programming
CISC 304.description: Propositional and predicate logic for general reasoning and advanced applications in knowledge representation in artificial intelligence and database, program correctness and programming semantics. Models, resolution, logic programming, and natural deduction.

CISC 442.title: CISC 442
CISC 442.name: Introduction to Computer Vision
CISC 442.description: Analysis of images and video to recognize, reconstruct, model, and otherwise infer static and dynamic properties of objects in the three-dimensional world. Geometry of image formation; image processing such as smoothing, edge and feature detection, color, and texture; segmentation; shape representation including deformable templates; stereo vision; motion estimation and tracking; techniques for 3-D reconstruction; image registration methods.

CISC 481.title: CISC 481
CISC 481.name: Artifical Intelligence
CISC 481.description: Programming techniques for problems not amenable to algorithmic solutions. Problem formulation, search strategies, state spaces, applications of logic, knowledge representation, planning and application areas.

CISC 483.title: CISC 483
CISC 483.name: Introduction to Data Mining
CISC 483.description: Concepts, techniques, and algorithms for mining large data sets to discover structural patterns that can be used to make subsequent predictions. Emphasis on practical approaches and empirical evaluation. Use of a workbench of data mining tools, such as the Weka toolkit.

CISC 484.title: CISC 484
CISC 484.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
CISC 484.description: Development of methods to learn to solve a task using examples. Explore different machine learning algorithms/techniques and discuss their strengths and weaknesses and situations they are or are not suited for.

CISC 450.title: CISC 450
CISC 450.name: Computer Networks I
CISC 450.description: Foundation principles, architectures and techniques employed in computer and communication networks. Focuses on mechanisms used in TCP/IP protocol suite. Topics include connection management, end-to-end reliable data transfer, sliding window protocols, quality of service, flow control, congestion control, routing, LANs, framing, error control, analog versus digital transmission, packet versus circuit switching, multiplexing.

CISC 464.title: CISC 464
CISC 464.name: Introduction to Network Security
CISC 464.description: Practical introduction to network security field. Covers material on cryptography, intrusions, denial-of-service attacks, worms, honeynets and other hot topics in network security.

CISC 436.title: CISC 436
CISC 436.name: Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
CISC 436.description: Concepts, methodologies, and tools in bioinformatics. Abstraction of biological problems for computational solutions. Genome sequencing and assembly, bio-sequence analysis and comparison and database search, dynamics programming, hidden Markov models, and phylogenetic trees.

MATH 210.title: MATH 210
MATH 210.name: Discrete Mathematics I
MATH 210.description: Elements of sets and logic. Relations, functions. Integers. Induction and recursion. Principles and techniques of counting. Graphs. Paths and circuits

MATH 241.title: MATH 241
MATH 241.name: Analytical Geometry and Calculus A
MATH 241.description: Functions, limits, continuity, derivatives. Polynomial, rational, exponential, hyperbolic, logarithmic, trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions. Definite and indefinite integrals and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus. Simple differential equations (separable ODE, linear ODE). ODE models leading to exponential growth and decay.

MATH 242.title: MATH 242
MATH 242.name: Analytical Geometry and Calculus B
MATH 242.description: Brief review of MATH 241; evaluation of limits by L’Hospital’s rule; applications of integration; integration techniques; parametric curves; polar coordinates; infinite sequences and series. Includes use of computers to perform symbolic, numerical and graphical analysis.

MATH 205.title: MATH 205
MATH 205.name: Statistical Methods
MATH 205.description: Descriptive statistics, graphical displays, sampling, variation, normal distribution, estimation, hypothesis testing, one-way analysis of variance, simple linear regression and goodness of fit. Laboratory covers use of statistical packages on mainframe and microcomputers.

MATH 350.title: MATH 350
MATH 350.name: Probability Theory and Simulation Methods
MATH 350.description: Introduces the basic theory of discrete and continuous aspects of probability theory. Topics include bivariate distributions, sums of independent random variables, moment generating functions, laws of large numbers and central limit theorem.

MATH 349.title: MATH 349
MATH 349.name: Elementary Linear Algebra
MATH 349.description: Systems of linear equations, linear combinations of vectors, and matrix algebra. Determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, similarity and diagonalization of square matrices. Vector spaces, linear dependence and independence, basis and dimension, linear transformations. Inner product spaces, orthogonality, orthogonal projections, fundamental subspaces. A software package may be used for the analysis and solution of linear algebra problems.

UNIV 401.title: UNIV 401
UNIV 401.name: Senior Thesis I
UNIV 401.description: Senior thesis for students working toward a degree with distinction.

PHYS 207.title: PHYS 207
PHYS 207.name: Fundamentals of Physics I
PHYS 207.description: First course in a sequence with PHYS 208 that provtitlees an introduction to physics for those in physical sciences and engineering. Emphasis on Newton’s laws of motion and conservation principles. These are applied to motion in a gravitational field, and to rotation of a rigtitle body. Integrates conceptual understanding with extensive problem solving.

PHYS 227.title: PHYS 227
PHYS 227.name: Fundamentals of Physics Laboratory I
PHYS 227.description: Introductory laboratory experience associated with the course content in PHYS 207.  This includes exploring projectile motion, linear and rotational dynamics, energy, momentum, and simple harmonic motion.

PHYS 208.title: PHYS 208
PHYS 208.name: Fundamentals of Physics II
PHYS 208.description: Second course in a sequence with PHYS 207 that provtitlees an introduction to physics for those in the physical sciences and engineering. Emphasis on electro- and magnetostatics in terms of forces, fields and potentials, with some elements of circuit theory. Furthermore, magnetic induction and Maxwell’s equations in integral form are introduced. Integrates conceptual understanding with extensive problem solving.
PHYS 208.prereq: PHYS 203 or PHYS 207, PHYS 227, MATH 241 or MATH 232

PHYS 228.title: PHYS 228
PHYS 228.name: Fundamentals of Physics Laboratory II
PHYS 228.description: Introductory laboratory associated with topics coverd in PHYS 208.  This includes investigaing the properties of Electric and Magnetic fields, simple circuits, and simple motors.

CHEM 103.title: CHEM 103
CHEM 103.name: General Chemistry I
CHEM 103.description: Matter, the changes that matter undergoes, and the laws governing these changes, with greater emphasis on atomic and molecular structure, chemicalbonding, and energy relationships. Properties of gases, liqutitles, soltitles and solutions.

CHEM 133.title: CHEM 133
CHEM 133.name: General Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM 133.description: Laboratory topics and techniques covered include: stoichiometry, gases, liqutitles, soltitles, atomic and molecular structure, chemical reactions in solution, and properties of solutions. 42h lab experiments.

CHEM 104.title: CHEM 104
CHEM 104.name: General Chemistry II
CHEM 104.description: Continuation and application of CHEM 103 with additional emphasis on chemical spontaneity, equilibrium, rates of reactions, electrochemistry and organic chemistry.

CHEM 134.title: CHEM 134
CHEM 134.name: General Chemistry Laboratory II
CHEM 134.description: This laboratory course is the second in a two-semester sequence designed (and required) for science and engineering majors. Covers thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium among gases, liqutitles and soltitles, equilibrium in solution, actitles and bases, electrochemistry, and nuclear chemistry.  Topics touched on briefly include transition elements and types and nomenclature of organic compounds. Descriptive chemistry of representative elements is interspersed throughout the course.  42h laboratory experiments.

CHEM 213.title: CHEM 213
CHEM 213.name: Elementary Organic Chemistry
CHEM 213.description: A survey of the fundamentals of organic chemistry. Topics include molecular structure, organic nomenclature, functional groups, isomerism and stereoisomerism, reaction mechanisms, and organic synthesis. Basic principles will be illustrated with examples of biological significance.
CHEM 213.prereq: CHEM 104, CHEM 134, or CHEM 102, or CHEM 105, or CHEM 112

CHEM 215.title: CHEM 215
CHEM 215.name: Elementary Organic Chemistry Laboratory
CHEM 215.description: A survey of elementary laboratory techniques that are useful to organic chemists. Separation and purification techniques and examples of typical organic reactions will be included.
CHEM 215.prereq: CHEM 104, CHEM 134, or CHEM 102, or CHEM 105, or CHEM 112

CHEM 321.title: CHEM 321
CHEM 321.name: Organic Chemistry I
CHEM 321.description: First half of two-semester survey of structure, synthesis, and reactions of organic compounds.

CHEM 325.title: CHEM 325
CHEM 325.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
CHEM 325.description: Laboratory work that introduces the basic laboratory techniques of organic chemistry.

BISC 207.title: BISC 207
BISC 207.name: Introductory Biology I
BISC 207.description: Molecular basis of life. Structure and function of cells, including signal transduction pathways. Energy transformations. Classical Mendelian genetics and the flow of information from DNA to RNA to proteins. Laboratory focuses on the testing of hypotheses, data analysis and scientific writing.

BISC 208.title: BISC 208
BISC 208.name: Introductory Biology II
BISC 208.description: Mechanisms of evolution. Physiology of multicellular plants and animals. Principles of ecology with emphasis on the biology of populations. Laboratory focuses on testing of hypotheses, data analysis and scientific writing. Animal and plant anatomy also studied.

BISC 401.title: BISC 401
BISC 401.name: Molecular Biology of the Cell
BISC 401.description: Introduction to the molecular biology of eucaryotes and procaryotes. Topics include structure and function of proteins and nucleic acids; replication and repair of DNA; biosynthesis of RNA and proteins; membranes, transport, composition and function of the eucaryotic cell, chromosomes, viruses, the immune system and recombinant DNA.

GEOL 105.title: GEOL 105
GEOL 105.name: Geological Hazards and Their Human Impact
GEOL 105.description: Geological processes and events that adversely affect humans and civilization. Methods for predicting and dealing with geological hazards. May be taken with a 1 credit lab, GEOL  115.

GEOL 107.title: GEOL 107
GEOL 107.name: Geology of Dynamic Earth
GEOL 107.description: Principles of physical geology and its application in interpreting earth processes. Laboratory covers titleentification of earth materials and the interpretation of topographic and geologic maps.

GEOL 115.title: GEOL 115
GEOL 115.name: Geological Hazards Laboratory
GEOL 115.description: Laboratory investigation of environmental geological processes and their impact on society: earthquakes, volcanoes, coastal hazards, rivers and streams, groundwater. titleentification of earth materials and study of earth processes using topographical, geological and tectonic maps.

GEOL 110.title: GEOL 110
GEOL 110.name: Earth's Evolving Systems
GEOL 110.description: History of the earth and its biota. Origins, evolution and mass extinctionsof major groups of organisms as demonstrated by the earth’s fossil record. Laboratory covers titleentification of basic fossil groups and exercises in interpreting Earth history.

CPEG 465.title: CPEG 465
CPEG 465.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity
CPEG 465.description: This cybersecurity course is an introduction to computer and network security and covers the foundation security policies and methods to provide confidentiality, integrity, and availability, as well as cryptography, auditing, and user security. Topics are reinforced with hands-on exercises run in a virtual machine environment.

EGGG 101.title: EGGG 101
EGGG 101.name: Introduction to Engineering
EGGG 101.description: Introduction to profession, including disciplines of chemical, civil, computer, electrical, environmental, and mechanical engineering. Prepares students for success through integration of: technical problem solving and engineering design, ethical decision-making, teamwork, and communicating to diverse audiences.
